item.title: Ask HN: Machine learning engineers, what do you do at work?
item.description: Machine learning engineers collaborate with non-technical people to create models using large amounts of data, often in the healthcare field. They spend time in meetings, preparing data, and analyzing data to forecast outcomes. Despite concerns about data security, access to information is readily available. Some engineers have had experiences where training documentation directed them to send SQL queries to production without proper permissions. comments

item.title: Le vieux Paris n'est plus
item.description: The text "Le vieux Paris n'est plus" by David A. Bell discusses the changing nature of Paris and how the old city is disappearing. It reflects on the transformation of the city and the loss of its historical charm. comments

item.title: OpenSSH introduces options to penalize undesirable behavior
item.description: OpenSSH has introduced new options in sshd(8) to penalize undesirable behavior and shield specific clients from penalties. The new options, PerSourcePenalties and PerSourcePenaltyExemptList, monitor client behavior and penalize them for repeated unsuccessful authentication attempts or causing sshd to crash. PerSourcePenalties will be enabled by default in the upcoming OpenBSD 7.6 release. Admins need to be aware of the consequences of inconsiderate NAT use when using these options. comments

item.description: A disaster was narrowly avoided as a plane cleared the runway just seconds before a potential collision. comments

item.title: Tom 7: Badness 0 (Three ways)
item.description: The text discusses different ways to access and experience the latest installment of Badness 0, including reading Knuth's Version and Epsom's Version in the SIGBOVIK 2024 proceedings, ensuring proper display in Chrome, and bathing in the flashing lights of Badness 0. It also mentions accessing the source code for a direct experience of "BUG" and provides information on compiling and using it. Additionally, the text mentions the availability of the source code under the GPL or GJPL licenses and promotes the author's YouTube channel and blog for further content. comments

item.description: A slow-spinning radio neutron star discovered by the University of Sydney researchers defies conventional understanding of neutron stars. comments

item.title: Replit used legal threats to kill my open-source project (2021)
item.description: The author of the text, Radon, worked at Replit as an intern and later created an open-source project that allowed users to run code in various programming languages online. When he shared his project with Replit, they initially responded positively but later accused him of unethical behavior and stealing their design. Replit threatened legal action to shut down the project, citing their increased size and financial resources. After receiving an official response from Replit, Radon's project will be back up soon. The author questions why Replit would use legal threats to bully him into shutting down the project. comments

item.title: Show HN: I created this land use visualisation for the Netherlands
item.description: This webpage uses hexagons to visualize land use in the Netherlands, with each hexagon representing 0.06% of the country's land. The color of each hexagon indicates a specific type of land use. Despite being densely populated, the Netherlands has a high number of solar panels, surpassing the entire continent of Africa. comments

item.title: Chebyshev approximation and how it can help (2012)
item.description: The text discusses Chebyshev approximation and how it can help individuals save money, make friends, and influence people. It highlights the benefits of using this method and its practical applications in various aspects of life. comments

item.title: Yes, you can play Duck Hunt without a television (but I can't)
item.description: The text discusses the history of Duck Hunt, a classic Nintendo game, and how it can be played without a television using a mechanical device from the 1970s. The device consists of a projector and a gun that requires specific batteries. It raises the question of whether it qualifies as a video game and describes the gameplay of shooting ducks projected onto a wall. The post also mentions a website with more information on the Nintendo mechanical Duck Hunt. comments

item.title: South Pole Water Infrastructure
item.description: This post discusses the water infrastructure at the South Pole, where fresh water is produced from snow despite extreme temperatures. The author, an infrastructure enthusiast, shares details about the system and how it operates in such harsh conditions. comments

item.title: Xv6, a simple Unix-like teaching operating system
item.description: Xv6 is a teaching operating system based on Unix V6, developed in 2006 and ported to RISC-V for the class 6.1810. The latest xv6 source code and text are available online. Feedback on using xv6 is welcomed, and suggestions for improvement can be sent to the course staff. comments

item.title: ASCII Silhouettify
item.description: ASCII Silhouettify is an app that converts images into ASCII silhouettes using uniformly filled geometric shapes. It can only handle flat graphics with minimalistic, high-contrast forms and does not render shading or gradients. The app uses traditional ASCII characters for output and can be accessed through a browser or command-line. Users can choose different output formats such as colored text or HTML. The app supports multiple image formats and has options for customizing the output palette. Installation and uninstallation instructions are provided for different operating systems. comments

item.title: What Is PID 0?
item.description: The text discusses the misconception around PID 0 in Unix systems. It explains that PID 0 does exist and is responsible for scheduling and power management, but is not shown to users through traditional APIs. The text criticizes the incorrect information found on the internet about PID 0, particularly stemming from a 16-year-old sentence on Wikipedia. It goes on to provide historical context and examples from Unix kernels to explain the role of PID 0 in different versions. It concludes by clarifying that PID 0 does not handle paging or virtual memory management as commonly believed. comments

item.title: Own a weather station? We want your data
item.description: The text is asking people who own weather stations to share their data. The data will be used for various forecasts including local, aviation, marine, rivers and lakes, hurricanes, severe weather, fire weather, sun/moon, long-range forecasts, climate prediction, and space weather. Additionally, past weather data and heating/cooling days are also of interest. comments

item.title: What happened to Captura? OSS maintainer burnout (2023)
item.description: Captura was a screen capture app for Windows that allowed users to capture screen, webcam, audio, and keystrokes. The app is no longer maintained, but the source code is still available on GitHub. The creator, who started the project as a high school student, decided to stop providing updates due to burnout and threats from individuals selling the app under a different name without crediting him. comments
